title: Proposed Planned Parenthood clinic in Visalia shut down by pro-life residents
description: Planned Parenthood Mar Monte's plans for a new Visalia clinic were temporarily quashed amid mounting controversy from some residents.
text_headers: Planned Parenthood's proposed Visalia clinic quashed amid mounting controversy
text: Proposed Planned Parenthood clinic in Visalia shut down by pro-life residentsNews Sports Tulare Entertainment Life Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSPlanned Parenthood's proposed Visalia clinic quashed amid mounting controversyJoshua YeagerVisalia Times-DeltaPlanned Parenthood Mar Monte's plans for a new Visalia clinic were temporarily quashed amid mounting controversy from some residents.  A public hearing had been scheduled for Monday's Visalia City Council meeting but was "continued indefinitely" at the request of Orosco Group, the project's developer. The hearing has since been removed from the meeting agenda."Our intent was to lease or sell a building, not to invite a forum for a national debate about abortion to the city council of Visalia," co-partner Patrick Orosco said.  "It has become that despite our best efforts."The nonprofit that provides family planning and healthcare services nationwide said it won't give up on its search for a new Visalia home."We were forced to give up our sale option due to strong objection from the community," said Lauren Babb, vice president of public affairs. "Our goal is to find a location to give care in Visalia, and we will continue working with community partners to make sure that happens."More:State constitutions vex conservatives’ strategies for a post-Roe worldThe Visalia Planning Commission approved the location on Mooney Boulevard in a 4-0 decision over some objections to the proposed clinic. Local developer David Paynter argued the clinic did not have sufficient parking and would cause protesters to disrupt shoppers at neighboring retailers Bed Bath & Beyond and Marshalls. Paynter manages the businesses, as well as nearby Sequoia Mall and numerous centers along Mooney.He appealed the decision to the Visalia City Council.A public hearing to determine the clinic's fate was postponed several times as controversy around the proposal grew, attracting passionate appeals from opponents and supporters of the clinic.Supporters pointed to the family planning services that the nonprofit provides, particularly to low-income Tulare County residents. However, critics objected mainly to Planned Parenthood's abortion services and what would have been a "highly visible" location in the city on one of its main thoroughfares."Our love for our neighbors is why we so strongly oppose efforts to perform abortions here in Visalia," Patricia June Boon, a leader of Tulare-Kings Right to Life, wrote in a recent Times-Delta opinion column.Babb told the Times-Delta that the Visalia clinic would not perform abortions on-site. She pointed out that Planned Parenthood has existed in Visalia for nearly a decade without a single protest or incident at its Stevenson Street clinic.Tulare County has the fourth-highest rates of teen pregnancy in California and ranks among the state's highest in sexually transmitted diseases, as well. Babb said that's one reason Planned Parenthood will remain committed to the region.More:Without Roe v. Wade, their abortions wouldn't have been possible"Tulare County is a low-income region. Our hope was to continue to expand healthcare here. I don't think we would've anticipated this outcome," Babb said. "Time is ticking as [Supreme Court decision Roe V. Wade] is being eroded. We have to serve California no matter what."Before the pandemic, Planned Parenthood's Visalia clinic served about 2,000 patients annually, 75% of whom are low-income. Babb said Planned Parenthood had been searching for a larger Visalia clinic for many years so that it could treat more patients and offer primary care services."We had no intentions of trying to rock the boat, so to speak, when we chose this (Mooney) location," Babb told the Times-Delta.
